questions.title: A Difficult Decision You Had to Make
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Difficult Decision You Had to Make'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have faced a moment when they had to choose between two important things. I remember a time when I had to make a very difficult decision. It taught me about priorities and sacrifice.

It was the month of March last year. My school's science exhibition was on the same weekend as my cousin's wedding in Chennai. I had worked on my project for three months, and my team needed me. But my cousin Priya was like an elder sister, and I had promised to be at her wedding.

I tried everything to find a solution. I asked my teacher if we could present earlier, but the judges were not free. I asked my parents about attending just the reception, but flights were too expensive. The catch was when my teammate Arjun called and said, "We can manage without you, but it won't be the same." I realized how much they needed me.

After thinking for hours, I made my choice. I called Priya and explained. She understood and said, "Your studies come first. We will video call." I went to the exhibition, and we won second place. Priya sent me photos, and we celebrated together in summer.

This experience taught me that difficult decisions don't always have perfect answers. I learned that people who truly care will understand our choices. I will always communicate honestly when facing tough decisions, and I won't let guilt stop me from doing what is right.

questions.title: A Hot Summer Day
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Hot Summer Day'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a day when the heat was so bad that even simple tasks felt impossible. I remember one such day during my summer vacation. It turned into an unexpected adventure and taught me to help others.

It was the 15th of May, during peak summer. The temperature had crossed 45 degrees. My mother asked me to stay indoors, but we had no milk. The shop was just ten minutes away, so I decided to go quickly.

I stepped out at 11 AM. The sun was blazing, and my shirt was wet with sweat within minutes. Halfway to the shop, I saw an old man sitting under a tree. He looked pale and was holding his chest. The catch was that nobody else was around, and he needed help. I rushed to him. He pointed to a phone number in his pocket.

I called the number. His son said his father had diabetes and must have fainted from the heat. I got glucose water from a nearby pharmacy. His son arrived in fifteen minutes and took him to the hospital. The old man held my hand and said, "God sent you today."

That day taught me to always look out for people who need help. I learned that we should be aware of others around us. I will never ignore someone in trouble, and I won't complain about small problems when others suffer more.

questions.title: A Time of Unexpected Kindness
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Time of Unexpected Kindness'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a moment when a stranger's kindness changed their day. I remember one such incident that made me believe in the goodness of people.

It happened on a rainy evening in July. I was coming home from tuition class. My bus stop was two kilometers away, and I had no umbrella. The rain was getting heavier. Worse, I realized I had lost my wallet at the tuition center.

I stood at a tea stall, shivering and worried. I had no money for the bus. My phone was almost dead. An elderly woman noticed me checking my pockets again and again. She asked, "Beta, what happened?" I told her I was stranded. The catch was that she not only gave me bus fare but also her umbrella. When I said no, she smiled and said, "I live nearby. You have far to go."

I took the bus home. My parents were relieved. Next day, I went back to return the umbrella and money. The shopkeeper said she was a retired teacher who often helped students. I found her house and thanked her. She invited me for tea, and we talked for an hour. She became like a grandmother to me.

That evening taught me that kindness comes from unexpected places. I learned that one small act of help can start a chain of goodness. I will always try to help others, and I won't hesitate to accept help when I need it.

questions.title: A Visit to the Doctor
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Visit to the Doctor'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have had a doctor's visit they dreaded. I remember one such visit that started with fear but ended with a lesson about courage.

It was a Monday morning in September. I had toothache for a week but hid it because I was scared of dentists. The pain became too much during dinner, and my mother noticed. She checked my mouth and found a bad tooth. Next morning, she took me to Dr. Sharma's clinic.

The waiting room had the sound of drilling. My heart was pounding. When my turn came, I wanted to run. My mother held my hand tightly. Dr. Sharma was kind. She showed me the instruments and explained what she would do. The catch was when she said, "The decay is deep. We need a root canal, not just a filling." I felt dizzy. But she added, "I'll give anesthesia. You won't feel pain."

The procedure took one hour. I felt pressure but no pain. Dr. Sharma talked to me the whole time about her son who was also scared of dentists. When it was over, she gave me a "Bravery Award" certificate and a sugar-free lollipop. My mother was proud of me.

That visit taught me that the fear of pain is often worse than the pain itself. I learned that facing fears with kind people makes everything easier. I will never delay medical care because of fear, and I won't let my imagination make things scarier.

questions.title: A Visit to the Seaside
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Visit to the Seaside'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have a memory of the sea that stays with them forever. I remember my first visit to Marina Beach in Chennai. It taught me to respect the power of nature.

It was during the Pongal holidays in January. My family visited Chennai, and my uncle promised to take us to the beach. I had never seen the sea before. I could not sleep the night before, imagining the endless water I had only seen in pictures.

We reached Marina Beach early morning. The first sight of the ocean took my breath away. It was bigger than I imagined. I ran towards the water, ignoring my uncle's warnings. The waves looked gentle. The catch was when a huge wave crashed into me and knocked me down. I was dragged a few meters before my uncle grabbed me. I swallowed salty water and coughed for minutes.

After I recovered, my uncle explained about undertow and currents. He showed me how to watch the waves before going in. We spent the rest of the day carefully - building sandcastles, collecting shells, watching fishermen. The sunset was the most beautiful thing I had seen.

That visit taught me that nature demands respect. I learned that I should never underestimate natural forces and should listen to experienced people. I will always be careful with new experiences, and I won't let overconfidence put me in danger.

questions.title: When I Met with an Accident
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'When I Met with an Accident'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a moment when life suddenly changed without warning. I remember the day I met with an accident while cycling. It left me injured but wiser about safety.

It was a Sunday afternoon in November. I had just learned to ride without training wheels and wanted to show off. My parents were at a neighbor's house two streets away. I decided to surprise them by cycling there. I was not supposed to use the main road, but I thought a short distance wouldn't matter.

I started confidently, feeling the wind in my hair. The road seemed empty. I pedaled faster. I was looking at a dog in a garden when I heard a loud horn. A motorcycle was coming, and I was on the wrong side. The catch was that I panicked and turned sharply instead of braking. My bicycle skidded on gravel, and I fell hard. The motorcyclist swerved, but my bicycle wheel went over my ankle.

People gathered and called my parents. My ankle was swelling, and I could not stand. Father rushed me to the hospital. The X-ray showed a hairline fracture. I wore a cast for six weeks. The motorcyclist, Mr. Rajan, visited me at home. He was not angry. He gently explained road rules to me.

That accident taught me that rules exist to protect us, not restrict us. I learned that one moment of carelessness can cause weeks of pain. I will always follow traffic rules, and I won't take risks just to show off.

questions.title: When I Witnessed an Accident
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'When I Witnessed an Accident'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have witnessed something that shook them deeply. I remember the day I saw a road accident. It taught me about emergency response and the fragility of life.
It was a Tuesday morning during Diwali vacation. I was sitting on our balcony, reading a book. Our apartment overlooks the main road. I was half-watching the traffic while turning pages.

Around 10 AM, I heard brakes screeching and then a thud. A delivery truck had hit a scooter at the crossing. The rider was thrown several feet and lay still on the road. The truck driver jumped out, looking shocked. People gathered but just stared. The catch was that nobody was calling for help. Everyone was arguing about whose fault it was while time was passing.

I ran inside and told my mother. She called 108 for an ambulance. My father went down to help. He had done a first-aid course. He knew not to move the injured man but checked if he was breathing. He asked someone to direct traffic. The ambulance came in fifteen minutes. Later we heard the man survived with a broken leg and collarbone.

That morning taught me that in emergencies, someone must take action instead of just watching. I learned that calling for help immediately is important. I will always remember to call emergency services first, and I won't be a passive bystander when someone needs help.

questions.title: A Day When the Lights Went Off
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Day When the Lights Went Off'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a power cut that ruined their plans. I remember a day when the lights went off for twelve hours. What started as a problem became one of the best days with my family.

It was a Saturday in April, during exam time. I had planned to study for my maths exam using my laptop. My sister had a project deadline. Father was working from home on a presentation. We all needed electricity.

At 9 AM, the power went off. We thought it would come back soon. But minutes became hours. My phone died, then my sister's tablet. The catch was that we had no backup, and the electricity board said there was a major failure. It would take until evening to fix. My study plan was ruined. We were all frustrated.

My mother suggested we make the best of it. We opened windows and played board games we had not touched in years. Father taught us chess, and I found I was good at it. We had lunch by candlelight. In the afternoon, we sat on the terrace talking about family stories I had never heard. When lights came back at 9 PM, we almost felt sad that our special day was ending.

That day taught me that our dependence on technology keeps us from connecting with each other. I learned that the best moments don't need screens. I will make time for family conversations regularly, and I won't let devices become more important than people.
